text:
How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion,

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we need to step away from the screens some, in social instances, while continuing to embrace them at work. I think IF someone can fill some of time spent in either class or work meaningfully, then they should use screens for this. With the pandemic NOT having totally ended we should mitigate contact with others WITH utilizing screens. WE should still embrace them.

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we need to step away from the screens some, in social instances, while continuing to embrace them at work. I think IF someone can fill some of time spent in either class or work meaningfully, then they should use screens for this. With the pandemic NOT having totally ended we should mitigate contact with others WITH utilizing screens. WE should still embrace them.

I think we should be careful about the amount of time spent on screens, and I think we should be careful about the content that we consume

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we need to step away from the screens some, in social instances, while continuing to embrace them at work. I think IF someone can fill some of time spent in either class or work meaningfully, then they should use screens for this. With the pandemic NOT having totally ended we should mitigate contact with others WITH utilizing screens. WE should still embrace them.

I think we should be careful about the amount of time spent on screens, and I think we should be careful about the content that we consume though. While needed for work, using it to substitute fully for all life is bad. We DO need meaningful face to face with loved ones, particularly if they are vaccinated and masked absolutely embrace, love, and see others. Substituting virtual beings and data for life can have quite negative effects, particularly for young and forming minds, for those who are often marginalized and shunned anyway, and for those who have difficulty being alone. We must engage, socially, going out of our way to include, safely, others in real life. It's important to do so. 

It's a sort of delicate balance, involving people while utilizing remote work and schooling can turn out well.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we need to step away from the screens some, in social instances, while continuing to embrace them at work. I think IF someone can fill some of time spent in either class or work meaningfully, then they should use screens for this. With the pandemic NOT having totally ended we should mitigate contact with others WITH utilizing screens. WE should still embrace them.

I think we should be careful about the amount of time spent on screens, and I think we should be careful about the content that we consume though. While needed for work, using it to substitute fully for all life is bad. We DO need meaningful face to face with loved ones, particularly if they are vaccinated and masked absolutely embrace, love, and see others. Substituting virtual beings and data for life can have quite negative effects, particularly for young and forming minds, for those who are often marginalized and shunned anyway, and for those who have difficulty being alone. We must engage, socially, going out of our way to include, safely, others in real life. It's important to do so. 

It's a sort of delicate balance, involving people while utilizing remote work and schooling can turn out well. It's a balance that I think we should strive for.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, we need to step away from the screens some, in social instances, while continuing to embrace them at work. I think IF someone can fill some of time spent in either class or work meaningfully, then they should use screens for this. With the pandemic NOT having totally ended we should mitigate contact with others WITH utilizing screens. WE should still embrace them.

I think we should be careful about the amount of time spent on screens, and I think we should be careful about the content that we consume though. While needed for work, using it to substitute fully for all life is bad. We DO need meaningful face to face with loved ones, particularly if they are vaccinated and masked absolutely embrace, love, and see others. Substituting virtual beings and data for life can have quite negative effects, particularly for young and forming minds, for those who are often marginalized and shunned anyway, and for those who have difficulty being alone. We must engage, socially, going out of our way to include, safely, others in real life. It's important to do so. 

It's a sort of delicate balance, involving people while utilizing remote work and schooling can turn out well. It's a balance that I think we should strive for. We need to improve our overall lives BUT we need to utilize screens sometime to do that. If we can minimize long horrid commutes via screens then, we should do this. We should also use that wasted commute time, now saved, to hang out with those we love, spend extra time with children/parents/friends.  Make NEW connections in real life using that time and saved resources. Take advantage, similarly of being able to get educated and improve your job skills via computers. Take up a hobby, involving others if possible. The world can be better and wider doing BOTH work with screens and expanding our social real world.  Lets live life more fully.

Wisely using screens for needed activities but eliminating them from unneeded ones. Shunning social media for news or time fillers and instead opting for real time meetings with friends, go out for coffee or better yet, a walk outside, with close friends. Put the screens away when we aren't at work or school. Open up the world.

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

I think IF someone can fill some of time spent in either class or work meaningfully, then they should use screens for this. With the pandemic NOT having totally ended we should mitigate contact with others WITH utilizing screens. WE should still embrace them.

I think we should be careful about the amount of time spent on screens, and I think we should be careful about the content that we consume though. While needed for work, using it to substitute fully for all life is bad. We DO need meaningful face to face with loved ones, particularly if they are vaccinated and masked absolutely embrace, love, and see others. Substituting virtual beings and data for life can have quite negative effects, particularly for young and forming minds, for those who are often marginalized and shunned anyway, and for those who have difficulty being alone. We must engage, socially, going out of our way to include, safely, others in real life. It's important to do so. 

It's a sort of delicate balance, involving people while utilizing remote work and schooling can turn out well. It's a balance that I think we should strive for. We need to improve our overall lives BUT we need to utilize screens sometime to do that. If we can minimize long horrid commutes via screens then, we should do this. Shunning social media for news or time fillers and instead opting for real time meetings with friends, go out for coffee or better yet, a walk outside, with close friends. Put the screens away when we aren't at work or school. Open up the world. 

We can do it. We can learn, become more, become better. Screens can help if we use them wisely as the tools they are. Avoid using them as crutches though. We can be better and screens can be a part of that improvement.
